thread.title: Fears intensify for survival of ancient maugean skate in Macquarie Harbour
thread.title_full: Fears intensify for survival of ancient maugean skate in Macquarie Harbour

author: Ted O'Connor
title: Fears intensify for survival of ancient maugean skate in Macquarie Harbour
text:
Map: Strahan 7468 
The critically endangered ancient maugean skate will likely die out in Tasmania within a decade unless salmon companies deal with water quality issues, an environmental group has said. 
Another company, Huon Aquaculture, has initiated legal proceedings against the Tasmanian Government for failing to protect the harbour's environment . 
Laura Kelly from Environment Tasmania called for the Government to enforce a baseline dissolved oxygen (DO) level at varying depths, to ensure the species' survival. 
"I've been told we can expect to see the species extinct within a decade, particularly because the areas needed to lay its eggs are devoid of oxygen," she said. 
"If oxygen levels start to get so low it threatens the survival of marine life in the harbour, fish farmers should have to withdraw their stock. 
"If this isn't done, all scientists will be able to do is tag the species and track their decline." 
Scientists have described the skate as a relic from the supercontinent Gondwana. 
The rare estuarine species was discovered in Bathurst Harbour in 1988, but appears to have since disappeared from that estuary. External Link: Maugean skate swimming. 
About 3,000 are now thought to be living in Macquarie Harbour, sharing the environment with intensive salmon farming. 
A scientific report into the health of the harbour has highlighted depleted dissolved oxygen (DO) levels and dead zones under leases . 
The report from the Institute of Marine and Antarctic Studies (IMAS) warned the skate's eggs faced harm from being laid in shallow waters with low DO levels. 
"There is a significant and increasing area of the seabed in Macquarie Harbour where the oxygen levels are highly reduced," the report said. 
"[This] has clear negative implications for the endangered maugean skate, and there is a need to better understand the significance of this for the future viability of the skate population in Macquarie Harbour." 
Due to the legal proceedings initiated by Huon Aquaculture, IMAS researchers who are studying the maugean skate declined to comment. Minister dismisses group as a 'front' 
Ms Kelly said the Tasmanian Government needed to provide more funding for research into the endangered species. 
"It's imperative [to get] independent government funding for research so the scientists don't feel pressure not to [speak out], because of the funding that they rely on from the salmon companies in the harbour," she said. 
Environment Minister Matthew Groom declined to say whether he was considering enforcing a DO threshold, but took aim at Environment Tasmania. 
"Any future actions will be guided by this expert research, and not by green front groups such as Environment Tasmania," he said. 
Mr Groom said research into the skate was ongoing, but declined to give detail. 
The Commonwealth Department of Environment's website lists priority for the development of a recovery plan for the species as "high".
